body.p:
You have just cause to be surprised at my silence,
but my numerous duties and engagements prevent me from answering
both correspondents, and even family letters. To make up for lost
time I intend sending a long letter, and will endeavor to continue writing
to one whom I hold in the highest esteem. I send herewith the corrected
copy of the Road to faith and intend presenting it to your publication
society, if it is worth their acceptance; with this condition that they will
always supply me at the publication price. I have added little or nothing
and made but few Emendations. Of the former I specify the ten com- maimonidean
mandments creed, of the latter, very little will meet your eye of an unsatisfac
tory nature. You are at liberty to correct any text I have not translated
properly; Hebrew has been rendered “I will turn the nations
to pray with pure lips” instead of the authorised version, I will render pure
the lips of the people.”

It grieved me to notice the useless discussion,
in the valuable pages of the Occident on the question of west Indian
citrons. Had the writers who so dogmatically insisted upon their being
Hebrew grafted, been at all acquainted with the Antilles, they would
never have breached the matter. In these Islands too much attention
is devoted to the staple production, as sugar, coffee &c to allow a
laborer's time to be wasted on the improvement of fruit trees. Of Jamaica
especially I can assert most positively that the Citron grows in its
original state, either where it was first planted, or where the wind has
scattered the seed, and it has taken root. The same may be said of all
fruit trees, they are met with on all the estates, but no care is bestowed
on them. The orange and shaddock and perhaps the line, may, now that
estates owners try to make every thing profitable on their lands, receive
a share of attention, but the citron and others of that family are useless to
except for making preserves, and grafting for that purpose would not pay
the cost of oranges, shaddocks, and lime juice are exported, citrons grow and
rot on the trees they may be had for the asking. The whole expense is confined
to gathering bringing them to town, packing, and freight to the states. One
of our brethren in Jamaica used to send an annual supply to the syna-
gogues by his slaves, free of cost, the present possessor of his estates
permits any one to pluck citrons, who will send for them. They grow only
in the mountainous districts, and labor being high, people demand good
wages to walk the distance, and bring them to town. Of late years, Mr. Kursheedt
was supplied from a quarter nearer to Kingston; but the citrons from that
place were neither as handsome nor of so good a quality as those from
the lofty Port Royal mountains. Mr. Levy, the gentleman who resides there,
and his uncle before him, were both men of strict religious principles. As
natives of Europe, and perfectly acquainted with the peculiar citrons
permitted to be used, they never grafted the trees. It must also be
recollected that our Portuguese brethren in Jamaica were presided over for many
years by eminent Chachamine?; the chief Chacham De Cordova, an eminent
scholar in biblical and profane knowledge, and whose manuscript
writings attest his profound acquirements. Surely, these pious & orthodox
persons would not have sanctioned the use of grafted fruit. Either then
the learned in America have passed an erroneous judgment, or all the Chachamin
in Jamaica were wrong, or spurious citrons have been shipped to your
congregations and packed off as genuine fruit. One thing must be borne
in mind that in Europe the citron is well tended, in the west Indies
neglected, and the difference of appearance has been imputed to grafting,
which I again repeat is not practised in Jamaica, whence you have
heretofore been supplied. You are at liberty to make use of this information
and name me as the author.

You have written Mr. Wolff again on the
subject of my reply to the attack on confirmation, but it has been

delayed so long, that it has now lost its interest.” At the time the
articles appeared, it was my intention to have replied; and the whole was
sketched out and only wanted writing it fully, when the shameless conduct
of Mr. Naar and his confederates in attempting to discharge me from my
post called forth all my energies to defeat their machinations, and left
me little leisure and less inclination for so trifling a matter. Success
attended my efforts; and an administration, whose supporters only sought
to do the congregations as much mischief as possible; was turned out to make
way for better men. Whilst this was in progress, and my daily bread at
stake, when the prospect of having to go and seek a living elsewhere stared
me in the face, could you suppose that I should sit down composedly
to reply to an opponent whose object and motive in assailing me arose
from malice? And had I done so, would my words have been free from
asperity? Smarting under wrong, would there not have been too much
bitterness in my reasoning? Jamaica was before me, my resignation
there too recent to have been forgotten, and the unhappy circumstances which
caused it were remembered. And was I further to commit myself? Was I
to answer a man who is a model of infidelity and unbelief, who does not
observe a single day in the year, as tho' he had been a sincere & upright
Israelite? Must I not necessarily have exposed his hypocrisy, and shown
that his solicitude about for our religion had its source in dislike to me
personally? I must have exposed the whole affair to vindicate confirmation
and myself, and this step would have widened the breach in the congregation
and led to further aggravation and ill feeling. Mr. Naar and I are now
reconciled and I hope soon by prudence and circumspection to restore
peace and good will among all parties, except Mr. M. B. Simmonds, whom
every one despises and dislikes, and who is a bad hearted man. All his
talent, and he has much, can never reestablish him in the favorable
opinion of the public. Meanwhile I have not been idle, but have been
preparing to strengthen and improve my position. Again, necessity has
compelled me to open a school, to give me bread, in case of rupture or
discontent in the congregation, necessity, not choice, has driven me to it for
I had hoped to sit down here and labor for the welfare of my flock as in
Jamaica. I have not been altogether unsuccessful. In another quarter
also I have been endeavoring to make provision for future subsistence. All
these projects trench upon my time, and exclusively with the writing of sermons engage my attention.
Depending on the faith of the congregation, I sent for my mother in law and
her mother who is eighty years old, and cannot easily move from place
to place. Cares have multiplied you see and have restrain my will, else
I would not be in St. Thomas. I detail, that you may make allowance
for my silence, and not attribute it to indolence or indifference. The good
effects of confirmation have more and more convinced me of its great
utility and tho' I have altered some of the formalities, I am not prepared
to abandon it. But why, let me ask, were not your observations levelled
against the ceremony, ? replied to by Dr. Lilienthal? He is not incapable
of defending it, and its advocacy concerns him who has the spiritual
care of thousands, more than poor me who have only 3 or 4 hundred to guard.
His reasons I cannot divine, unless he thought your arguments irrefutable,
which, in my opinion, the are not. It does not appear, that in your long
ministry, you have been able, without confirmation, to introduce a more
serious observance of the sabbath in Philadelphia, or the abolition of
mixed marriages, or the foundation of Jewish Schools. In Jamaica
I did not resort to confirmation; I accomplished all these objects without
it; here however I find it a useful instrument in keeping the sheep within
the fold; and thro' the children have wrought upon the parents so that some
determined sabbath breakers have been won from their evil courses. That confirmation
has answered the purpose I intended it to serve, knowledge of our religion to
the young, reflection upon past misdeeds and serious resolutions to amend on
the path of the old. Its value has been tested here, and found beneficial, and as the
most orthodox, as Plessuer?, say, Adler and others are in its favor, it cannot be
termed heterodoxical. I do not pin my faith on it, but with God's help, I hope
to further its already usefulness. No child shall be called to the sepher who is
ignorant of the fundamental principles of Judaism but yet I will not make
confirmation compulsory, the king of Denmark will however do so. It may suit
the unbeliever to disapprove of it, because he reveres nothing; this cause, added
to personal ill will to me and Mr. Wolff, was the reason of Mr. Naar's philippic.
It grieved me to find your powerful pen enlisted in the service of irreligion,
but your dislike of any thing approaching reform instigated you to throw
disparagement on a valuable aid to our religion in these times when license

of speech, thought, and conduct is dignified by the name of liberty of
conscience and action. I cannot account for your championship in any other
manner. There were points in Mr. Naar's communication savoring of the grossest
infidelity; whoever read it must have been convinced that it emanated from a
rank Deist; yet how bland were your corrections of those points, and how determined
your onslaught on confirmers and confirmation. The pages of the Occident may yet, on
some future occasion be open to my advocacy of confirmation, when my mind is less
harassed; and be assured that the past will not then be forgotten. Till then, I resume
my defence of the promise, not the oath taken made at the first ceremony, and shall be
able to produce the warrant of scripture for its introduction. Polemics do not
appear to be Mr. Naar's forte; politics whether discussed in caucus, stage waggon,
or groggery are more suited to his taste, else he would not have made himself
so ridiculous by stating that the Immortality of the Body instead of its resurrection
was one of the doctrines he could not approve of. Shade of maimonides! dost
thou not feel rebuked at by the superior understanding of the Quondain? mayor
of Elizabeth Town? But my dear Mr. Leeser, you will never be able to write
down confirmation; it will maintain its ground and spread itself in America
as elsewhere, and time may yet behold in you and of its warmest defenders
one word more on this subject; refer to the 4th no of the First Fruits, and note
that confirmation had my best wishes, before the thought of St. Thomas entered my
mind. You will find an article headed Bar-Mitzva or Confirmation in which
I expressed a desire for its adoption in Jamaica.

Your last letter was exceedingly interesting. The sketch of
Rabbi Moshe Katzenellenbogen so graphic and illustrative of the Jewish charac-
ter and studies in Poland and Russia. Your opinion is correct of our people's
being the most clever among mankind. Even if their studies are not practically
useful in a busy world, they sharpen the intellect and fit then the mind for
understanding any thing. A Polack or Russian Israelite having once obtained
a little refinement and polish is able to make his way in any pursuit whether
literary, scientific, or mercantile. It yet remains to be seen what effect
the immense immigration of our people into the states will have on religion
generally. The problem will be solved in the western world whether
Christianity shall not fall at the feet of Judaism. On that continent where
the fullest liberty meets the most rigorous despotism of body and mind, where
American and Russian institutions border on each other the truth of prophecy
will first enlighten man, and its accomplishment take place. Whilst every
Jewish heart bleeds at the miseries of our Russian brethren, it is apparent
that some great change is at hand in the fortunes of our people. Nicholas
is not influenced by any other motive to act as he does towards them and
the Catholics, than to acquire absolute dominion rule over the consciences
of his subjects and to make them all conform to one religion as they obey
one sovereign who is solo master of their lives of his and liberties. It seems
as tho' he spoke in the language of an ancient oppressor Hebrew.
It is a mighty and gigantic project displaying his daring genius not even
Antiochus Epiphanes dared to go so far. Nicholas wars not against
Judaism alone, he takes up arms against Christendom & mohammedan
ism. Our generation will not witness his success or that of his successors;
but how well does he realize Ezekiel's description of the “Prince of Rosh
Meshic and Tubal” destined to be broken with his multitudes on the
mountains of Israel. Really the longer we live, the better do we
comprehend scripture, and our ablest commentators were on these
historical revelations less enlightened than we who cannot hold a
candle to them in knowledge. Prophecy sheds a stronger light the longer
it turns. When Russia was an obscure and barbarous country which of
our commentators could have pointed to it unknown as she it was to be
the spot whence the last opponent to Israel's restoration and peace
should issue? At this day, who can scruple to doubt that the ?
dynasty was forseen by the prophet? Depend on it, no prayers, no
entreaties will sway Nicholas from his purpose, no montefiores will
succeed; he will promise, but will not relax his iron determination.
He will modify his ?, but their end and intention will remain
the same. He will possibly permit a larger emigration of those who
can afford to buy the privilege of departing, but he will not the
less persevere in his oppression. Martyred blood will be shed and perhaps
when that avails not, he will drive Israel from his land as Pharoah
did. In politics the danger is as imminent as in Religion, Turkey is

already in his grasp. Austria will succumb, Prussia will follow, unless
the German nations combine for common safety. And whither shall the
millions of Israel in these countries fly to for refuge and protection save to Western
Europe, or more probably to the United States? Therefore the hypothesis
that America is to be the chosen soil whereon mankind will first be
illumined is not so very extraordinary. Meanwhile let us pray for the
messiah coming as did our pious forefathers, and await it with devout
and confident hearts.

Have you yet broken a lance against Rabbi Wise
as you anticipated? I was prepared for something more satisfactory
and convincing than his logical reasoning in the Occident. Possibly his
words have suffered by translation but part of his arguments appear to me
very contradictory. For example in page 160 June No of Occident he says.
“The chief precept of our religion is to be holy that is to love God &c. Inferior
to this precept is the one to acknowledge God expressed in the first com
mandment & If one really acknowledge him we shall love Him and thereby
become holy! First Rabbi Wise makes the love of God paramount to the
acknowledgment of God, and in the next line tells us that the effect of
acknowledging him will lead us to love Him. If love then be the chief
it must lead to acknowledgment and not acknowledgment to love. Beside
I was always taught that acknowledging the Divine Being is the first
principle to be taught. In the Hebrew it is so; love of God being a consequence
of recognizing and acknowledging him the same in the Decalogue, in
the Creed of Maimonides and Albo. The neo-judaical opinions of Rabbi
Wise are not in harmony, on this point, with the law and prophets.
Prayers, generally, is subjective; but surely scripture presents many of an
objective character Moses on behalf of Miriam, Samuel for the people &c &c
Persons pray for each other disinterestedly hoping that the effect may
be objective. “If the proper object and purpose of prayer” I quote page 158
be the reflective effect upon the spirit and heart of him who prays”
thus one should never pray for our fellow creatures; all our ideas would
be confined, in prayer, to our own spiritual and temporal improvement.
The subjective and objective effect of prayer is too refined a distinction
to be understood by the generality of our people, and Rabbi W. has not
explained this difficult point clearly. Your emphatic objection in
page 158 has my cordial support. Of course, Rabbi W. wants no temple
no national restoration, no messiah, he only wants a Hebrew. Why not
recommend the mutilation of the prophecies, or the leaving out, when
revising the law, all such passages as relate to Israel's redemption and
restoration, such as Hebrew. Rabbi W's opinions are not new to
me. The modern reformers generally have attached to the removal
of evil disabilities and the recognition of Israelites to the rights of
citizenship, their views of messiah's coming. They do not ask much,
but what conception can they have of the prophecies, if they thus
confine the future glory of Israel to the enjoyment of such doubtful
good? The conclave of American Rabbins are right however in
seeking to establish a minhag America. It is most necessary
if only to make Judaism and synagogue worship understood
by Christians. I almost shudder at the prejudices which the
conduct in some synagogues must excite in the Christian mind.
Whilst therefore condemning some of the principles evolved by
Rabbi Wise as the mouthpiece of the conclave, the project
has my best wishes. Why do you not start up and effect the
same for the Sephardim of whom you are the head, both by
length of service, talent &c. They require it their synagogue
discipline is exceedingly lax, and needs restoration.

I am compelled to conclude abruptly as a vessel
is just about to sail. My health is so bad that this letter has

body.p:
been taken up 5 or 6 times to be completed. I enclose the corrected copy of the “Road to faith”
and present it in my name to your publication society. Mrs. Nathan sends her love to you
and regards to all friends whom I will name another time. Hoping that the Almighty
will give you health and strength to discharge your ministerial duties during the
Holidays, and that your prayers on behalf of your congregation and self may
be heard on high

If you see my friend Vaz? of Jamaica, tell him not to be angry for I will
write him very soon. I hope he is well.
